title: Chinese Developer Woos U.S. Investors With 12% Yields
summary: Heavily indebted Kaisa has to pay up amid slowing economy, trade tensions and Hong Kong protests-and after a 2015 default. For American investors, a bond yield above 12% cures most ills.

title: Purdue Paid Out $10.4 Billion to Sacklers as Opioid Crisis Grew, Report Finds
summary: A special committee of Purdue's board traced the money distributed by the OxyContin maker. OxyContin manufacturer Purdue Pharma LP generated more than $10 billion since 2008 for the Sackler family members who own the company, according to a report that will influence the debate among state and local governments over how much of that money should be returned.

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Approve Marijuana and Driver's License Bills
summary: Cannabis legalization will be on the 2020 ballot and illegal immigrants will be able to apply for driver's licenses. New Jersey lawmakers sped through a host of legislation on the last voting session of the year, including a measure putting marijuana legalization before voters and one allowing driver's licenses for illegal immigrants.

title: More On-the-Fence Democrats Back Impeachment of Trump
summary: Ahead of a Wednesday vote, House leaders prepare to pick managers for expected Senate trial. WASHINGTON-More Democrats from competitive House districts said they will back the impeachment of President Trump, putting the effort on track to pass this week despite some fears that their position could put their seats at risk.

title: To Fight Vaping, New York City Bans Nearly All Flavored E-Cigarettes
summary: The law aimed at curbing vaping, which is increasingly popular among young people, takes effect next July. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday signed into law a bill that bans the retail sale of nearly all flavored e-cigarette products, which health officials have said are popular among young people.

title: Warren Doubles Down on Economy to Rejuvenate Campaign
summary: Democratic presidential candidate touts proposal to boost Social Security benefits at Iowa town hall. WASHINGTON, Iowa-Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren is trying to get back to talking about increasing economic opportunities and programs for the middle class, after scrutiny over Medicare for All blunted her momentum in the 2020 race.

title: Amazon Blocks Use of FedEx Ground for Prime Shipments
summary: Amazon cites a decline in FedEx performance heading into the final holiday push. Amazon.com Inc. is blocking its third-party sellers from using FedEx Corp.'s ground delivery network for Prime shipments, citing a decline in performance heading into the final stretch of the holiday shopping season.

title: Boeing to Suspend 737 MAX Production
summary: Plane maker will halt production of grounded jetliner involved in two fatal crashes. Boeing Co. said it would suspend production of its 737 MAX jetliner, in an escalation of the crisis facing the giant plane maker that will ripple through the global aerospace industry.

title: Students at New York High School Stage Protests Over Alleged Discrimination
summary: Student leaders say there have been years of transgressions at a Manhattan high school. Students at prestigious Beacon High School in Manhattan talked of peers throwing around the N-word.

title: The Incredibly Incurious Mr. Comey
summary: The IG report shows investigators who didn't investigate Steele.. James Comey has finally admitted some "sloppiness" over the surveillance warrant for former Trump campaign aide Carter Page. The former FBI director should re-read Inspector General Michael Horowitz's report because it lays out a record of willful incuriosity about Christopher Steele and his dossier that is hard to credit as mere incompetence.

title: Achieving Quantum Wokeness
summary: Political correctness barges into a computer science breakthrough.. Two months ago researchers at Google published a paper in Nature saying they had achieved "quantum supremacy." It's a term of art, meaning Google's quantum computer had zipped through some calculating that would take eons on a classical supercomputer.

title: The Voter Theft That Wasn't
summary: A Wisconsin judge enforces the law. Liberals cry foul.. Liberals are howling that Republicans are trying to steal the 2020 election after a state judge in Wisconsin on Friday ordered more than 200,000 voters removed from the rolls to protect ballot integrity. The complaints as usual are overwrought.

title: Global Economy Regains its Footing
summary: Growth steadies as prospects rise in U.S. and China; Europe remains a weak spot. The global economy is regaining some of its footing, with recent economic and trade developments in the U.S. and China offering some comfort that the slowdown is easing.

title: A Job for Adam Schiff
summary: The chairman should look into how he was taken in by Russian disinformation.. Now that his impeachment work is over, here's a new assignment for Adam Schiff: To investigate whether the bad intel in the Christopher Steele dossier was there because the former British spy was a sloppy partisan-or because he was the patsy in a Russian disinformation campaign.

title: Lessons From the Tory Landslide
summary: A vindication for the Burkean idea that nationalism can advance liberalism.. Last week's U.K. general election revealed two political dynamics that the rest of the world should study closely.

title: A Short History of Wall Street Journal Hedcuts
Impeachable or Not, Trump's Foreign Policy Is Reckless
summary: He begins with disruption-breaking things-but lacks the patience and attention to rebuild.. As Congress debates whether President Trump's dealings with Ukraine constitute an abuse of power, Americans should ask what Mr. Trump's behavior says about his foreign policy. Mr. Trump's conduct sends conflicting signals and risks big mistakes.

title: The '1619 Project' Gets Schooled
summary: The New York Times tries to rewrite U.S. history, but its falsehoods are exposed by surprising sources.. 'So wrong in so many ways" is how Gordon Wood, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian of the American Revolution, characterized the New York Times 's "1619 Project." James McPherson, dean of Civil War historians and another Pulitzer winner, said the Times presented an "unbalanced, one-sided account" that "left most of the history out." Even more surprising than the criticism from these generally liberal historians was where the interviews appeared: on the World Socialist Web Site, run by the Trotskyist Socialist Equality Party.

title: Forgiveness Isn't Divine When It Comes to Student Debt
summary: Those who struggle the most are dropouts who owe a few thousand. Here's a plan to target help to them.. The Democratic presidential primary so far has been a race to see who can present the most generous taxpayer-funded plan to fix every problem from health care to higher education. President Trump has noticed and is reportedly eager to develop a competing plan to tackle student debt. There is plenty he can do to help with the burdensome cost of college, but the solutions on the table miss the mark.

title: Notable & Quotable: Fiorina for Impeachment
summary: 'But . . . Fiorina did not rule out voting for him again.'. From a Dec. 16 CNN.com report:

title: 'The Russian Job' Review: Feeding the Enemy
summary: Few remember that in the early 1920s America supplied food to a starving Soviet Union, quite possibly preventing its collapse.. The American troops who landed in Russia to help reverse the Bolshevik coup of 1917 did little to change history, but cast as imperialist villains, they were useful to Soviet propagandists charged with rewriting it. In "The Russian Job: The Forgotten Story of How America Saved the Soviet Union From Ruin," Douglas Smith tells the remarkable tale of a different, largely forgotten yet infinitely more effective intervention.

title: The 2010s Have Been Amazing
summary: Health, wealth and the environment are all better than ever.. The 2010s have been the best decade ever. The evidence is overwhelming. Start with the United Nations Development Report. Framed as a warning about inequality, it plays down the good news: "The gap in basic living standards is narrowing, with an unprecedented number of people in the world escaping poverty, hunger and disease."

title: Federal Spending Agreement Adds Up to Nearly $1.4 Trillion
summary: Pact funds government through the rest of fiscal year; not much time for a vote. WASHINGTON-A nearly $1.4 trillion spending agreement released Monday would fund the federal government through the rest of the fiscal year, permanently repeal a number of health-care-related taxes and raise the legal age for purchasing tobacco products to 21.

title: Partners Group Buys U.S. Eye-Care Company in $2.2 Billion Deal
summary: Partners is acquiring a majority stake in EyeCare Partners, which has over 450 locations across 13 states. Partners Group Holding AG said it is adding one of the largest U.S. optometry and ophthalmology services groups to its portfolio of health-care investments in a transaction that a person familiar with the matter said values the business at $2.2 billion including debt.

title: Netflix Reveals New Data on Overseas Growth
summary: Streaming service discloses detailed subscriber information for operations outside the U.S. for the first time. Netflix Inc. released new metrics revealing how fast it is expanding in specific regions of the world, in an effort to persuade Wall Street to focus more on its growth outside the increasingly competitive U.S. market.

title: In Published Work, Male Scientists Sing Their Own Praises More
summary: New study finds men often use stronger language in medical research, which may contribute to gender differences in pay and promotion. Male scientists portray their studies as "unprecedented," "remarkable," "excellent" and "novel" more often than female scientists, a new study finds, which may contribute to gender differences in pay and promotion in the medical world.

title: What's in a Hedcut? Depends How It's Made.
summary: A 40-year-old Wall Street Journal tradition gets recrafted with technology. The main difference was in the hair.

title: University of Oklahoma Is Sued Over Troubled $250 Million Dormitory
summary: Developer behind a luxury dormitory says university reneged on commitments. The developer behind a luxury dormitory sued the University of Oklahoma, accusing the institution of breaking its pledge to support the $250 million student-housing project.

title: Acosta Wins Court Approval for Prepackaged Reorganization Plan
summary: Marketing-services company will eliminate about $3 billion in debt. Acosta Inc. will make a speedy exit out of chapter 11 two weeks after filing for bankruptcy protection with a prepackaged reorganization plan that hands control of the marketing services company to its lenders in exchange for eliminating about $3 billion in debt.

title: Boeing's Crisis Management Keeps Falling Short
summary: The plane maker's perceived pressuring of regulators to fast-track recertification of the 737 MAX has backfired. Boeing 's decision to temporarily halt production of its 737 MAX jet is a tough pill to swallow, but adds little information about the actual financial risks faced by the company. The bigger problem is how its upper management is handling the crisis.

title: Obama's FBI and the Press
summary: The media establishment congratulated itself for getting duped into supporting an abuse of power.. Thanks to a report from the Obama-appointed inspector general of the Justice Department, now everyone knows the truth about 2016. The Obama administration misled the U.S. Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court and wiretapped an American who supported the presidential campaign of the party out of power. One of the many sad lessons is that no American can count on even the most celebrated members of the establishment press to shine a light on such abuses.

title: How About a Little Pipe Music at Geffen Hall?
summary: The planned $550 million 'reimagination' of the home of the New York Philharmonic should include a real organ.. When officials at Lincoln Center, earlier this month, announced details of the planned $550 million "reimagination" of Geffen Hall, home of the New York Philharmonic, one detail was conspicuously absent: whether the new space would have a pipe organ.

title: Coca-Cola Resurrects Post of Chief Marketing Officer
summary: Some companies have re-evaluated the CMO title as marketing changes. Two years after eliminating the role of chief marketing officer in favor of a more powerful chief growth officer, Coca-Cola Co. is resurrecting the CMO post.

title: How Much Is Your Old Menorah Worth? One Collector Might Know
summary: Resume Subscription. Tsadik Kaplan makes a living selling antique Jewish objects to wealthy clients.

title: U.S. Stocks Rise to Records as Growth Worries Ease
summary: Fresh data signals better-than-expected factory production and consumer spending in China. Stocks on both sides of the Atlantic clinched records Monday as investors doubled down on bets that some of the biggest risks to financial markets are clearing.

title: Bain Capital's New Technology Fund Makes Maiden Investment
summary: Bain has held a first closing of the new fund and is adding an investment professional from Hellman & Friedman to its team.

title: Intel Deepens AI Push With $2 Billion Purchase of Habana Labs
summary: Purchase gives Intel another way to lure data-center customers. Intel Corp. is expanding its push into the artificial-intelligence market with an approximately $2 billion deal for Habana Labs, an Israel-based AI chip-making startup.

title: Kentucky's New Governor Ends Medicaid Work Requirement
summary: Democrat Andy Beshear reverses policy by GOP predecessor that was enmeshed in court fight. Kentucky's new Democratic governor, Andy Beshear, halted the state's push to add a work requirement for Medicaid recipients, a policy pursued by his Republican predecessor that became entangled in court fights.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Pull Back on Improving Chinese Economic Data
summary: Value-added industrial output in China rises 6.2%, beating expectations. U.S. government-bond prices fell Monday following better-than-expected Chinese economic data, driving yields higher after they fell last week.

title: Voting-Machine Parts Made by Foreign Suppliers Stir Security Concerns
summary: Technology linked to companies under authoritarian governments highlights risks; China-based suppliers don't always mean Chinese-made parts. A voting machine that is widely used across the country contains some parts made by companies with ties to China and Russia, researchers found, fueling questions about the security of using overseas suppliers, which has also sparked scrutiny in Washington.

title: Trump Administration Extends Deadline for Affordable Care Act Enrollment
summary: Consumers get three additional days to sign up after reports of widespread technical problems. People will have more time to sign up for health coverage on the federal Affordable Care Act exchange after some experienced problems using the website Sunday, Trump administration officials said.

title: U.S., Mexico Appear to Settle Labor Controversy in USMCA
summary: A Mexican official had questioned provision in legislation in Congress adding attachés south of border. The U.S. and Mexico appeared to resolve an 11th-hour labor dispute that had threatened to sour a planned congressional vote on a new North American trade agreement.

title: 'Fine Line': Styles Over Substance
summary: Former One Direction member Harry Styles's new album is filled with classic-rock references, with a result more imitative than original..

title: U.S. Levies Sanctions on Two South Sudanese Officials
summary: The two officials are accused of perpetuating conflict in the East African nation. The U.S. imposed sanctions on two senior South Sudanese officials for allegedly perpetuating conflict in the East African nation, the U.S. Treasury Department said.

title: Graham Hints Trump Could Draw Down U.S. Troops in Afghanistan
summary: Sen. Lindsey Graham, visiting Kabul, says cutting troop presence from 13,000 to 8,600 would leave U.S. with 'very lethal punch'. KABUL-President Trump could order a sharp reduction in U.S. troops in Afghanistan without endangering the Pentagon's ability to prevent another catastrophic terrorist attack on American shores, a close ally of the president said Monday.

title: Bolloré Called Foul on Nissan's Ghosn Probe Days Before Ouster
summary: Boardroom clash highlights how secret moves by executives last year are still disrupting management. Three days before he lost his job in October, then- Renault SA chief Thierry Bolloré demanded an independent audit of Nissan Motor Co. 's investigation into Carlos Ghosn, citing concerns the probe was tainted by conflicts of interest, according to a letter by Mr. Bolloré.

title: Former Serco Executives Charged With Fraud
summary: The charges come after Serco paid a fine and entered a deferred prosecution agreement to resolve a probe of the company. The U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office charged two former executives with participating in an alleged scheme to overcharge the U.K. government for an electronic monitoring contract.

title: Former National Security Adviser Flynn to Be Sentenced on Jan. 28
summary: Judge rejects a bid by Flynn's lawyers to dismiss case; he pleaded guilty in 2017. WASHINGTON-A federal judge Monday rejected a last-ditch effort by former national security adviser Michael Flynn's attorneys to dismiss the criminal case against him and set a sentencing date of Jan. 28.

title: Upbeat Chinese Economic Data Buoy Commodities
summary: Copper and oil among the industrial raw materials benefiting from latest trade developments. Improving economic data in China are fueling hopes that global growth will accelerate in 2020, supporting a host of commodities from oil to copper.

title: Trump Threatens to Bypass Debate Commission, Attacking Its Integrity
summary: President accuses nonpartisan group of bias, proposes debating Democratic nominee in unspecified different forums. WASHINGTON-President Trump threatened to pull out of a system of presidential campaign debates that has been in place for more than three decades and accused the nonpartisan commission that oversees them of bias.

title: Investors Doubt OPEC Cuts Can Boost Oil Prices
summary: Recent rallies in crude stalled on concern reduced production won't meaningfully curtail supply. Easing trade tensions and production cuts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries have boosted oil prices recently, but some investors remain dubious that even those long-awaited developments will be enough to push crude beyond its recent trading range.

title: Who Read What: 2019
summary: Here's what Robert Iger, Zadie Smith, Andrew Yang, Twyla Tharp and more read this year.. Each year we ask more than 50 leaders and luminaries from literature, business, politics and the arts to name the best books they've read during the year. You could spend all day reading the full list-and all year reading the books.

title: Novartis Drops Asthma Drug After Disappointing Trial Results
summary: Fevipiprant performed no better than a placebo for patients with moderate to severe asthma. Novartis AG said it was abandoning a potential blockbuster drug for asthma after it failed late-stage trials, puncturing the company's hopes of pioneering a novel way to treat the respiratory disease.

title: Organ Transplantation Needs More Organs
summary: In 2018, there were 36,529 organ transplants from 17,570 donors. But there are currently more than 113,000 patients on the waiting list for an organ transplant.. David Weill claims there isn't an organ shortage for transplantation. He is wrong ("Supply Isn't the Problem With Organ Transplants," Review, Dec. 7). In 2018 there were 36,529 organ transplants from 17,570 donors. But there are currently more than 113,000 patients on the waiting list for an organ transplant. While Dr. Weill says that deceased donors can provide up to eight organs for transplantation, that is the exception-most deceased donors provide around three organs. Living donors provide one organ. Lack of sufficient organs is the main problem facing transplantation in the U.S.

title: Food Stamps and Helping the Poor to Work
summary: We are seeing a segment of the workforce, usually single mothers, who want to work but cannot work too many hours because they would lose their federal, state and local subsidies.. Regarding your editorial "Food Stamps in Good Times" (Dec. 5): It strikes me that the food stamp program (and every such program) should be reformed to make sure that whatever help is being provided is intended to enable the person to graduate from government subsidies.

title: Cultural Cohesiveness Helps Utah's Economy
summary: But the exclusive social environment largely offsets the economic virtues.. In his eloquent report on "Why Utah Has Become America's Economic Star" (Cross Country, Dec. 7), Stephen Moore doesn't include one other very interesting statistic which is significant and telling. Of all U.S. states, Utah has the highest rate of children graduating from high school living with both birthparents. Home is more than an address.

title: America's 'Forever War' Retreat Is China's Gain
summary: Where the U.S. has disengaged, Xi Jinping and his Communist cabal have stepped in.. Regarding Josh Hawley's "End 'Forever Wars' and Face China's Threat" (op-ed, Nov. 25): Mr. Hawley rightly identifies China as this country's principal geopolitical challenge. Yet in dismissing "forever wars" in the Middle East, he overlooks the region's importance to Sino-American competition.

title: All Real Politics Is Local, But Impeachment Is Not
summary: This brings to mind the experience of a career military officer who attempted a run for Congress in his upstate New York district, hoping to be a force in guiding U.S. foreign policy.. Daniel Henninger suggests that Democrats will likely be disappointed with voters' response to the party's "Take Down Trump Project" ("Fractured Democratic Fairy Tales," Wonder Land, Dec. 5). This is spot on and brings to mind the experience of a career military officer who attempted a run for Congress in his upstate New York district, hoping to be a force in guiding U.S. foreign policy. When campaigning throughout his district, he was astonished that nobody cared about his views on this subject. All they wanted to know was what he intended to do about the price of milk. He lost his bid.

title: China Ditches NBA Playbook in Reaction to Soccer Star's Tweet
summary: The response from Beijing to Mesut Özil after he criticized the country's treatment of Uighurs was far less aggressive than its attack against an NBA executive two months ago. Arsenal had already been in crisis mode for weeks. Stuck in its worst season in a generation, the last thing the English soccer club was prepared for was its highest-paid player aiming a broadside at China.

title: Lawyers Are the Valeant Saga's Winners
summary: Neither Bausch Health nor its shareholders are complete beneficiaries of the company's settlement. Why trade stocks when you can litigate the aftermath instead?

title: An MMA Fighter Takes a Deep Breath and Goes to Work
summary: Resume Subscription. Only an MMA fighter would consider a version of underwater rugby the perfect activity for a rest day. Ilima-Lei Macfarlane, the undefeated Bellator women's flyweight world champion, heads to the pool on down days to train with Deep End Fitness in San Diego.

title: Canada Widens Deficit Forecasts
summary: Government cites cost of tax cuts, pension obligations in projecting shortfalls over next half decade. OTTAWA-Canada's re-elected Liberal government said it would be recording markedly wider-than-projected deficits over the next half decade, while signaling its intent to keep the fiscal taps open to help buoy economic prospects.

title: SEC Is Expected to Propose Further Loosening of Auditor Independence Rules
summary: New rules would give audit firms more discretion in assessing conflicts of interest. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's planned changes to auditor independence rules would loosen regulation of audit firms, giving them more discretion in assessing conflicts of interest in their relationships with companies they audit, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: London, New York and Hong Kong Share a Troubled Future
summary: Their international orientation doesn't fit comfortably in a less globalized, more nationalist world. In rankings of the world's international financial centers, London, New York and Hong Kong regularly dominate the top three spots. All boast the financial, physical and human infrastructure needed to conduct business across borders while sharing an openness to the world rooted in history and culture.

title: Space-Tech Startup Vector Launch Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Sequoia Capital-backed satellite company enters chapter 11 with deal to sell its GalacticSky platform to Lockheed Martin. Space-technology company Vector Launch Inc. has filed for bankruptcy, blaming its demise on venture-capital backer Sequoia Capital's decision not to provide additional funding for its development efforts.

title: Therese Tucker on Starting a Tech Company at 40
summary: Hear how the BlackLine founder dealt with the financial risks of entrepreneurship in WSJ's 'Secrets of Wealthy Women Podcast'. Therese Tucker had wanted to start her own software company for years. She had plenty of experience and knew she could run a business.

title: 'Protobilly: The Minstrel & Tin Pan Alley DNA of Country Music 1892-2017' Review: Eclectic Evolution
summary: A three-disc set reveals the urban underpinnings and shifting sounds of country music..

title: For CEOs, It's a Whole New Job
summary: Along with having to deal with globalism, nationalism, trade wars, AI, big data and cybersecurity, CEOs are increasingly expected to take stands on social issues. Chief executives entered the decade waiting for the next shoe to drop. The 2008 financial crisis drove entire industries to the brink, and CEOs spent the initial years of economic recovery conserving capital, slow-walking hiring plans and keeping a close eye on fragile global markets.

title: Investors in China's 5G Revolution Are Too Hopeful
summary: Adoption of 5G phones in China is a promising growth trend, but investors may have already gotten carried away. Chinese consumers will likely buy a lot more 5G phones next year-but perhaps not enough to justify investors' recent enthusiasm for the sector.

title: European Stocks Hit All-Time Record
summary: The Stoxx Europe 600 is on track for its best performance in a decade. Long-suffering investors in European stocks have something to celebrate, with the region's benchmark equity index hitting its first record in more than four years thanks in part to the lifting of geopolitical clouds.

title: Anti-Fur Activism Is on the Rise. What Does That Mean for Canada Goose?
summary: As animal rights activism ramps up, parka purveyors are providing non-fur options. UNDER THE "New Arrivals" section of the e-commerce site for status label Canada Goose, shoppers will find parkas like the "Sanford" and "Macmillan." These coats check nearly all the classic Canada Goose boxes-they're cocooning, they sell for around $1,000, and their left sleeves are affixed with the 62-year-old brand's red badge. Just one thing's missing. Like a Big Mac without the special sauce, the hoods of these coats lack Canada Goose's signature-and highly polarizing-coyote-fur trim. Though the brand has long made furless outerwear, that's not what it's known for or what makes up the bulk of its offerings-a scenario that is slowly beginning to change.

title: When Spotify Insists You Love 'Let It Go' and Lady Gaga
summary: The streaming giant is recapping subscribers' listening habits, going back a whole decade, and some don't like what they're hearing. Sarah Iqbal can't stand Lady Gaga. Spotify says otherwise.

title: Breast Implant Recall Creates Difficult Decision for Women
summary: After Allergan recalled certain textured breast implants because of a link to a rare cancer, women are navigating competing risks. The first time Michelle Peterson heard that there might be a problem with her breast implants was when a friend at work told her they had been pulled off the market. Mrs. Peterson spent the weekend researching the connection between her specific type of breast implant and a rare cancer.

title: How the U.S. Women's Basketball Team Won a Pay Raise
summary: Team USA's stars usually play overseas in the WNBA's off-season. But not this year.. The marketplace for the best women's basketball players in the world is a curious one. They can make more than $1 million when they play in Russia, China and Turkey. And they were paid a maximum base salary of $117,500 last season in the United States.

title: Gifts for the "Extreme Self-Care" Person In Your Life
summary: From a deeply relaxing facial that's not for your face to a total body overhaul on the coast of Spain, these 14 gifts that are all about (extreme!) wellbeing. Whether you self-gift these self care-themed gifts is up to you. A bar that's so much more.

title: Why Uber Is Shrinking Its Global Food-Delivery Menu
summary: The online takeout sector has unappetizing economics but can still give investors big gains. Investors' newfound taste for profits instead of growth-at-all-costs is triggering a wave of consolidation in the global meal-delivery sector.

title: In Impeachment, Tribalization of Politics Becomes Almost Complete
summary: Trump ran with little use for the Republican establishment, but enters the House impeachment debate with virtually complete support from that establishment. When Donald Trump launched his 2016 presidential bid, he did so almost as an independent, openly disdainful of the Republican Party establishment, and enjoying little support within it.

title: Protests Over India's New Citizenship Law Widen
summary: Critics of legislation, which disadvantages some Muslim immigrants, say Prime Minister Modi is undermining country's secular foundation. NEW DELHI-Protests against a new citizenship law that disadvantages some Muslim immigrants have spread across the country, with critics assailing what they call Prime Minister Narendra Modi's attempts to rewrite India's secular political underpinning.

title: New York Fed Adds $86.4 Billion in Day of Key Money-Market Pressures
summary: Operations are aimed at ensuring financial system has enough liquidity to keep short-term borrowing rates stable. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $86.4 billion in liquidity to financial markets.

title: Nigeria's Detention of Journalist Reflects Escalating Media Crackdown
summary: New Jersey senators and State Department urge release of U.S.-based activist, who was violently rearrested by security services in nation that is one of America's top counterterrorism allies. Few people outside Nigeria noticed when armed agents of the west African nation's security services in August snatched from his hotel room a U.S.-based journalist and activist who runs an online news website.

title: A Small-Minded Argument Against a 17-Game NFL Schedule
summary: There's talk about expanding the regular season. You don't need to be a Jets fan to think that's a bad idea.. The NFL, the country's most prosperous professional sports outfit, is considering expanding its regular season. The idea at the moment? Adding another game, to make it a 17-contest campaign.

title: Protests Paralyze Lebanon's Search for New Prime Minister
summary: Country's president postpones parliamentary consultations intended to reinstall former prime minister Saad Hariri. BEIRUT-An upswell in Lebanon's protests has paralyzed the search for a new prime minister, as political gridlock deepens the country's economic crisis.

title: NYC Mayor's Aides Communicate in Encrypted Messages
summary: As more government employees use apps like Signal, watchdog groups worry about transparency. Top aides to New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio sent messages back and forth on a recent Sunday afternoon, asking about the mayor's coming schedule and whether he would visit a Queens neighborhood where a sewage backup flooded many homes.

title: U.S. Expelled Two Chinese Embassy Officials Suspected of Espionage
summary: In September incident, the pair and their wives improperly drove onto a military facility in Virginia. WASHINGTON-The U.S. quietly expelled two Chinese Embassy officials on suspicions of espionage after they improperly drove onto a sensitive U.S. military facility in Virginia in September, two U.S. officials familiar with the matter said.

title: NBCUniversal CEO Steve Burke to Retire in 2020
summary: Jeff Shell to become the media company's CEO on Jan. 1. Comcast Corp. said Steve Burke, chief executive of NBCUniversal, plans to retire next August following the Summer Olympics in Tokyo.

title: China's Xi Jinping Voices Support for Hong Kong Leader's Handling of Protests
summary: Move underscores Beijing's backing for Carrie Lam's efforts to curb antigovernment unrest despite public rebuke in local elections. Chinese President Xi Jinping praised what he called the courage and commitment of Hong Kong's embattled leader, Carrie Lam, underlining Beijing's support for her handling of monthslong antigovernment protests despite a public rebuke of the establishment in local elections last month.

title: Bloomberg Campaign Kicks Off 'Long Haul' Strategy in North Carolina
summary: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg's strategy is to campaign in the state beyond the Super Tuesday primary. CHARLOTTE, N.C.-Billionaire Michael Bloomberg's presidential campaign, which has so far invested more than $100 million on TV ads, launched the ground-game portion of its operation Sunday, opening a field office in a state where most other Democrats have none.

title: How Drones Changed the Way This Photo Pro Works
summary: Corey Rich, an adventure photographer and author of 'Stories Behind the Images,' on the magic of hovering photo assistants, duct tape's versatility and elitist cycling gear. I never thought I'd be an elitist mountain biker, but turns out it's one of those sports where the tool you're using can make a huge difference in the amount of joy you get. Niner's Jet 9 RDO bike has this incredible geometry that allows it to just flow over the trail. I never thought I would say things like that, but I really appreciate the bike's suspension and the thrill it brings me. My mountain bike lives in the back of my Toyota Tacoma all summer long and anytime I can squeeze in an hour-long ride, I do.

title: Stocks to Watch: Boeing, Uber, DuPont, Heico
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Monday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Monday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Regal Owner Cineworld to Buy Cineplex for $1.65 Billion
summary: Deal creates North America's largest cinema operator. The owner of Regal cinemas has agreed to buy Canada's Cineplex Inc. for $2.18 billion Canadian dollars ($1.65 billion), a deal that creates North America's largest cinema operator.

title: It's Not You. Clothing Sizes Are Broken.
summary: Startups use body-scanning analytics to tackle decades-old problem with nonstandard sizes. Christopher Moore has a doctorate in physics from MIT and has worked on projects ranging from tracking the world's oil supply to searching for new cancer drugs. His latest gig is turning out to be the hardest: Helping shoppers find their correct clothing size.

title: Private Texas Border Wall Caught in Legal Fight
summary: Government wins restraining order halting construction over concerns $40 million barrier, being built with private funds, could change course of the Rio Grande. McALLEN, Texas-An effort to build a privately funded wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, as the Trump administration's efforts progress slowly, is running into trouble over concerns that its design may alter the border itself.

title: H&M's Strategic Shift Begins to Bear Fruit
summary: Hennes & Mauritz saw fourth-quarter sales rise to $6.59 billion, pushing the company's shares higher. The owner of H&M reported stronger quarterly sales, a sign the fast fashion giant's efforts to navigate changing shopper habits and increased competition are starting to pay off.

title: Chinese Home Builders' Favorite Funding Ploy Is Under Threat
summary: Presales of uncompleted housing have surged in recent years. Now one city has proposed controlling them more tightly.. The favored funding source of China's real-estate developers is under scrutiny in one of the country's largest urban areas, posing a threat to a sector that has stretched creative financing to its limits.

title: U.S. Envoy to North Korea Calls for Talks to Resume
summary: Stephen Biegun, in Seoul, also criticized recent weapons tests and threats. SEOUL-The U.S. envoy to North Korea on Monday reaffirmed Washington's desire to resume stalled nuclear talks with Pyongyang, publicly urging the regime to return to the negotiating table.

title: ESG Funds Draw SEC Scrutiny
summary: Wall Street's growing foray into impact investing has regulators questioning investors' ESG criteria.

title: Exploring the Hollywood of the Australian Outback
summary: Deep in the desert of New South Wales, a pair of old mining towns now draw movie buffs looking for 'Mad Max' and a giant stiletto. SITUATED IN THE far west of New South Wales, Broken Hill is Australia's longest-running mining town. For a time in the late 1800s it had the world's richest deposits of lead, zinc and silver. But I have little interest in mining. My fascination with Broken Hill and the neighboring town of Silverton is purely cinematic. "The Road Warrior" (1981), titled "Mad Max 2" in Australia, was shot here; so were many scenes from "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert" (1994) and the cult classic "Wake in Fright."

title: Bruin Sports Capital Buys Marketing Firm From WPP
summary: Deal values Two Circles, which works for sports leagues including the NFL, at $42 million. Bruin Sports Capital, a holding company investing in sports media, marketing and technology companies, said it has agreed to buy a majority stake in sports marketing agency Two Circles from advertising giant WPP PLC.

title: Cisco Wins Legal Challenge in Battle Against Chinese Counterfeits
summary: Networking-gear giant seeks to enlist rivals to fight knockoffs. Cisco Systems Inc. has won a legal battle against counterfeit versions of key networking equipment, securing an injunction that requires big online marketplaces, including Amazon . com Inc. and Chinese rival Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. to halt the sale of some knockoffs.

title: Make Your Job Application Robot-Proof
summary: It takes planning to make sure AI gatekeepers don't bounce your résumé-sometimes for arbitrary reasons-before a human can make a call. Job seekers often spend hours online researching employers and polishing their applications and résumés. Then they hit send.

title: Uber Is in Talks to Sell Its India Food-Delivery Business to a Rival
summary: A deal could be unveiled as early as this week. NEW DELHI- Uber Technologies Inc. is in talks to sell its food-delivery business in India to a local rival, according to people familiar with the matter, a potential boost for the American company as Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi seeks a path to profitability.

title: GOP Senators Seek Quick Acquittal for Trump. The President Wants More.
summary: With impeachment looming, many Republicans want a speedy trial without witnesses; Trump wants vindication. WASHINGTON-President Trump wanted Ukraine to help legitimize his 2016 election, show that his predecessors abused political power and raise doubts about a rival in the 2020 election.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Research Fuels Debate Over E-Cigarettes as Smoking-Cessation Device
summary: 'There's just an incredible disagreement within the public-health community'. Researchers and public-health experts are locked in a debate about whether e-cigarettes should serve as a harm-reduction tool for smokers, as a new generation of young people becomes addicted to nicotine and roughly half a million people in the U.S. die each year of smoking-related causes.
